trial_identification.studytitle: A comparison of oral prednisolone and oral dexamethasone in children with croup: a prospective, randomised, double blinded multicentre trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Oral Prednisolone vs oral Dexamethasone (in two different doses) in children with croup: Randomised Clinical Trial comparing the improvement in Westley Croup Score.
trial_identification.trialacronym: ToPDoG (Trial of Prednisolone / Dexamethasone oral Glucocorticoid)

interventions.interventions: Group 1 - oral prednisolone 1 mg/kg oral liquid, single dose; Group 2 - oral dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg oral liquid, single dose;
interventions.comparator: Group 3 - oral dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg oral liquid, single dose

primaryOutcome.outcome: Westley Croup Score (a validated measure of croup severity, based on clinical observations of stridor, retractions, air entry, cyanosis, and level of consciousness)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 12 hours after the treatment is administered

primaryOutcome.outcome: Unscheduled medical re-attendance rate, as assessed by follow-up telephone call

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of stay in the Emergency Department
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From time of triage to discharge-ready time and actual discharge time

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of hospital admission or observation
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From time of triage to discharge-ready time and actual discharge time

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Admission rate to Emergency Department Observation ward
Need for nebulised adrenaline (epinephrine), as recorded by treating staff, ie whether or not nebulised adrenaline was administered (decision at the discretion of treating doctor).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Prior to oral steroid dose, after oral steroid dose (during initial enrolment visit)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Admission rate to Intensive Care Unit
Need for definitive airway (tracheal intubation or surgical airway), as recorded by treating staff, ie whether or not a definitive airway was placed (decision at the discretion of treating doctor).
Number of additional doses of steroid given after trial drug
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During the 7 days post-treatment (including the period of initial enrolment visit)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hospital re-admission rate for croup symptoms (stridor or breathing difficulty), as assessed by follow-up telephone call
Hospital re-admission rate for non-croup symptoms
Adverse clinical events, other than vomiting (for example skin rash, changes in behaviour or appetite), as reported by treating staff and as reported by caregivers at follow-up telephone call
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During initial enrolment visit, during 7 days post-treatment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Clinical diagnosis of croup Age 6 months to 10 years Weight no more than 20 kg Parents contactable by telephone Parents speak English
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: High clinical suspicion of an alternative diagnosis, Known allergy to prednisolone or dexamethasone, Immunosuppressive disease or treatment, Steroid therapy in past 14 days, Enrolment in this study in past 14 days

trial_design.concealment: Dispensing rack dispenses numbered, otherwise indentical opaque bottles of medication, in set sequence as packaged. Weight-based dosing of medication with different concentrations, ensures same volume of 0.3ml/kg for all subjects. Palatability affects outcome measures (vomiting), therefore smell and taste of the 3 treatments are not controlled for.
trial_design.sequence: Computerised randomisation process administered by clinical trials pharmacist and stratified per centre.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This clinical trial is designed to test whether the three commonly used oral steroid treatment regimes for croup, are equally effective. Children will receive one of the three treatments, decided by a random process, and their improvement and outcomes monitored by investigators who are blinded to the treatment received.
